source.name: City of Melbourne / Yarra City Council
source.notes: Based on City of Melbourne and Yarra City Council guidelines. Only plastics #1, #2, #5 accepted. Glass has SEPARATE purple-lid bin. Aerosol cans NOT in yellow bin.

materials.name: Newspaper
instructions: Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
Remove any plastic wrapping first
notes: One of the most commonly recycled materials
commonMistakes: Don't bag newspapers in plastic — place loose
Don't include wet or heavily soiled newspaper

materials.name: Magazines and catalogues
instructions: Remove any plastic wrapping
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Glossy paper and staples are fine — no need to remove
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic wrapping or plastic inserts

materials.name: Junk mail and flyers
instructions: Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Glossy and coloured paper is fine
commonMistakes: Don't include laminated or plastic-coated items

materials.name: Office paper and printer paper
instructions: Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Shredded paper should be placed in a paper bag or envelope so it doesn't scatter
commonMistakes: Don't include laminated paper
Don't include paper with heavy glitter or foil

materials.name: Letters and envelopes
instructions: Place in the yellow-lid bin
Window envelopes are OK — no need to remove the plastic window
notes: Plastic windows are separated during processing
commonMistakes: Don't include padded or bubble-wrap envelopes — they go in rubbish

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove any polystyrene packing inside
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Flatten to save space — large boxes can be cut down to fit
commonMistakes: Don't include waxed cardboard
Don't include polystyrene or bubble wrap packing

materials.name: Cereal boxes and food packaging boxes
instructions: Remove the plastic liner inside (rubbish)
Flatten the box
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Thin cardboard/boxboard is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic liner — it goes in rubbish

materials.name: Egg cartons (cardboard)
instructions: Remove any egg residue
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Cardboard egg cartons only — not polystyrene
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene egg cartons — they go in rubbish

materials.name: Pizza boxes
instructions: Remove any leftover food
Flatten the box
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Small amounts of grease are OK
commonMistakes: Don't include boxes soaked with grease or food — heavily soiled boxes go in rubbish

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten the bag
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Brown and white paper bags both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include paper bags with plastic or foil linings

materials.name: Wrapping paper (non-metallic)
instructions: Remove any tape, ribbons, and bows
Scrunch test: if it stays scrunched, it's paper and recyclable
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Only plain paper wrapping — not metallic, glittery, or plastic-coated
commonMistakes: Don't include metallic or glittery wrapping paper — it goes in rubbish
Don't include cellophane or plastic wrap

materials.name: Water bottles (PET #1)
instructions: Empty the bottle
Remove the label/wrapper if possible
Leave lid on — but note loose lids are NOT accepted separately
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: PET #1 clear bottles only
Eligible for 10c refund via Victoria's Container Deposit Scheme (CDS Vic)
commonMistakes: Don't include coloured PET bottles — only clear #1
Don't put bottles inside plastic bags

materials.name: Soft drink bottles (PET #1)
instructions: Empty the bottle
Remove the label/wrapper if possible
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: PET #1 clear bottles — must be clear plastic
Eligible for 10c CDS Vic refund
commonMistakes: Don't crush bottles — leave them intact for sorting

materials.name: Milk bottles (HDPE #2)
instructions: Empty the bottle
Rinse briefly
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: HDPE #2 plastic — accepted in Melbourne's yellow-lid bin
One of the most commonly recycled plastics
commonMistakes: Don't include milk cartons here — cartons have their own entry
Don't include the separate plastic lid if it detaches — loose lids fall through sorting

materials.name: Laundry detergent bottles (HDPE #2)
instructions: Must be completely empty
Rinse briefly
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: HDPE #2 plastic — highly recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include laundry pods packaging (soft plastic)
Don't include if product remains inside

materials.name: Cleaning product bottles (HDPE #2)
instructions: Must be completely empty
Leave trigger spray on
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: HDPE #2 plastic accepted
Trigger sprays can stay attached
commonMistakes: Don't include if still containing product

materials.name: Shampoo and conditioner bottles (HDPE #2)
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Usually HDPE #2 — check the number on the bottom
commonMistakes: Don't include sachets (soft plastic — goes in rubbish)

materials.name: Hand wash and soap bottles (HDPE #2)
instructions: Must be completely empty
Leave pump on
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Pump mechanism is recycled with the bottle
commonMistakes: Don't include refill pouches (soft plastic — goes in rubbish)

materials.name: Dishwashing liquid bottles (HDPE #2)
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Includes both hand dishwashing and dishwasher detergent bottles
commonMistakes: Don't include dishwasher tablet wrappers (soft plastic)

materials.name: Yoghurt tubs (PP #5)
instructions: Empty the tub
Rinse briefly
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: PP #5 plastic — accepted in Melbourne
Foil lids can be scrunched and added to your aluminium foil ball
commonMistakes: Don't include the foil lid loose — scrunch it into your foil ball

materials.name: Butter and margarine tubs (PP #5)
instructions: Empty the tub
Rinse briefly
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: PP #5 rigid plastic tubs accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include tubs with large amounts of product remaining

materials.name: Ice cream containers (PP #5)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: PP #5 rigid containers accepted
commonMistakes: Must be clean — rinse out residue

materials.name: Plastic food containers (PP #5)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Only PP #5 rigid containers — check the number on the bottom
NOT all plastic food containers are accepted — only #1, #2, #5
commonMistakes: Don't include containers marked #3, #4, #6, or #7 — those go in rubbish
Don't include polystyrene (#6) containers

materials.name: Plastic meat trays (#2 or #5)
instructions: Empty and remove absorbent pad
Rinse the tray
Check the number — only #2 or #5 accepted
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Only rigid plastic #2 or #5 meat trays accepted
Polystyrene (#6) foam meat trays are NOT accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene foam meat trays — they go in rubbish
Don't include the cling wrap — soft plastic goes in rubbish

materials.name: Aluminium foil
instructions: Scrunch foil into a ball at least the size of a tennis ball
Keep adding to the ball over time
Place in the yellow-lid bin when large enough
notes: Small pieces fall through sorting machines — scrunching into a ball is essential
Must be free of food
commonMistakes: Don't put small flat pieces of foil in — scrunch them first
Don't include foil-lined packaging (e.g. chip packets) — that's not pure foil

materials.name: Metal cans (aluminium and steel)
instructions: Empty the can
Rinse briefly
Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: All metal food and drink cans accepted
Drink cans eligible for 10c refund via CDS Vic
commonMistakes: Don't crush cans — sorting machines identify shape
Don't put cans inside plastic bags

materials.name: Metal lids from bottles and jars
instructions: Collect metal lids together
Place inside a metal can and pinch the top shut to contain them
Place the can in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Loose small metal lids fall through sorting — contain them inside a can
Only METAL lids — not plastic lids
commonMistakes: Don't put loose metal lids in the bin — they fall through machinery
Don't include plastic lids — they go in rubbish

materials.name: Milk cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove the plastic cap — caps go in rubbish
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Melbourne accepts milk cartons in the yellow-lid bin
Remove caps as loose plastic lids are not accepted
commonMistakes: Don't leave caps on — remove plastic caps
Don't flatten — leave 3D for sorting

materials.name: Juice cartons and juice boxes
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove the plastic cap or straw
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Melbourne accepts liquid paperboard cartons
Includes Tetra Pak and gable-top cartons
commonMistakes: Remove plastic caps and straws — they go in rubbish

materials.name: Soy milk and plant milk cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove plastic cap
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: UHT and long-life cartons accepted
commonMistakes: Remove the plastic cap — loose plastic lids not accepted

materials.name: Stock and broth cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove plastic cap
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Liquid paperboard cartons accepted
commonMistakes: Remove the plastic cap

materials.name: Glass bottles
instructions: Empty the bottle
Place in the PURPLE-LID glass bin — NOT the yellow-lid bin
notes: Melbourne has a SEPARATE purple-lid bin for glass
All colours of glass accepted
Many bottles eligible for 10c CDS Vic refund
commonMistakes: Don't put glass in the yellow-lid recycling bin — use the purple-lid glass bin
Don't include broken glass — wrap in newspaper and place in rubbish

materials.name: Glass jars
instructions: Empty the jar
Place in the PURPLE-LID glass bin — NOT the yellow-lid bin
notes: Goes in the separate purple-lid glass bin
Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't put glass jars in the yellow-lid bin — use the purple-lid glass bin
Don't include ceramic or porcelain containers

materials.name: Food scraps
instructions: Place in the green-lid FOGO bin
Use a kitchen caddy with compostable liner to collect scraps
notes: All food scraps accepted: fruit, vegetables, meat, bones, dairy, bread, rice, pasta
Melbourne's green-lid bin is FOGO — Food Organics Garden Organics
commonMistakes: Don't put food scraps in the yellow-lid recycling bin — they contaminate recycling
Don't use regular plastic bags — only newspaper or certified compostable liners

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in the green-lid FOGO bin
notes: All fruit and veg scraps accepted, including citrus and onion
commonMistakes: Remove produce stickers and rubber bands first

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in the green-lid FOGO bin
Wrap in newspaper if preferred to reduce odour
notes: Melbourne's FOGO accepts all meat and bones
Processed at high-temperature commercial composting facility
commonMistakes: Don't put meat in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Bread, pasta, and rice
instructions: Place in the green-lid FOGO bin
notes: Cooked or uncooked — both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic bread bag — that goes in rubbish

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place in the green-lid FOGO bin
Small amounts of liquid dairy can be absorbed with newspaper
notes: Accepted in Melbourne's FOGO green-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't pour large volumes of liquid milk into the bin — absorb with newspaper

materials.name: Eggshells
instructions: Place in the green-lid FOGO bin
notes: Crush for faster breakdown
commonMistakes: No need to wash

materials.name: Tea bags and coffee grounds
instructions: Place directly in the green-lid FOGO bin
Paper coffee filters accepted
notes: Coffee grounds are excellent for composting
commonMistakes: Don't include coffee capsules (e.g. Nespresso) — return them via manufacturer program

materials.name: Garden waste
instructions: Place in the green-lid FOGO bin
Cut large branches to fit inside the bin
notes: Melbourne's green-lid bin accepts both food and garden waste (FOGO)
commonMistakes: Don't include treated timber or painted wood
Don't include soil or rocks
Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Flowers and garden prunings
instructions: Remove any plastic wrapping, string, or wire
Place in the green-lid FOGO bin
notes: Cut down large stems to fit
commonMistakes: Don't include floral foam (oasis) — it's plastic and goes in rubbish

materials.name: Food-soiled paper and cardboard
instructions: Place in the green-lid FOGO bin
notes: Food-contaminated paper goes in green-lid, not yellow-lid
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
Must be completely empty
notes: Melbourne does NOT accept aerosol cans in the yellow-lid recycling bin
This differs from some other Australian cities
commonMistakes: Don't put aerosol cans in the yellow-lid bin — they are NOT accepted in Melbourne
Don't puncture or crush

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
Or return to REDcycle collection bins at Coles/Woolworths (if available)
notes: Plastic bags jam sorting equipment at recycling facilities
NEVER put recyclables inside a plastic bag
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic bags in the yellow-lid recycling bin — they tangle in machinery

materials.name: Soft plastics and cling wrap
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: The 'scrunch test': if you scrunch it and it stays scrunched, it's soft plastic — goes in rubbish
REDcycle at some supermarkets may accept (check availability)
commonMistakes: Don't put soft plastics in the yellow-lid bin — they jam machinery

materials.name: PVC plastics (#3)
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Plastic #3 (PVC) is NOT accepted in Melbourne's yellow-lid bin
Only plastics #1, #2, and #5 are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put #3 plastic in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: LDPE plastics (#4)
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Plastic #4 (LDPE) is NOT accepted in Melbourne's yellow-lid bin
Includes squeeze tubes, some lids, and flexible packaging
commonMistakes: Don't put #4 plastic in the yellow-lid bin — only #1, #2, #5 accepted

materials.name: Polystyrene (#6) and styrofoam
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Plastic #6 (polystyrene) is NOT accepted in Melbourne's yellow-lid bin
Includes foam cups, foam trays, foam packaging, and rigid polystyrene
commonMistakes: Don't put polystyrene in recycling — it contaminates the recycling stream
Don't include foam meat trays — they go in rubbish

materials.name: Other plastics (#7)
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Plastic #7 is NOT accepted in Melbourne's yellow-lid bin
Includes mixed or multi-layer plastics
commonMistakes: Don't put #7 plastic in the yellow-lid bin — only #1, #2, #5 accepted

materials.name: Loose plastic lids and caps
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Loose plastic lids are NOT accepted in Melbourne's yellow-lid bin
They fall through sorting machinery
Remove plastic lids from cartons before recycling the carton
commonMistakes: Don't put loose plastic lids in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Disposable coffee cups have a plastic lining that makes them unrecyclable
Bring a reusable KeepCup — most Melbourne cafés offer discounts
commonMistakes: Don't put disposable coffee cups in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Chip packets, lolly wrappers, and snack packaging
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Made from mixed materials (plastic and foil) — not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put foil-look wrappers in recycling — they are not aluminium foil

materials.name: Tissues and napkins
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Too contaminated and degraded to recycle
Clean paper napkins can go in the green-lid FOGO bin
commonMistakes: Don't put tissues in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Paper towels
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
Or place in the green-lid FOGO bin if food-soiled
notes: Paper towels are too degraded to recycle
The empty cardboard tube CAN be recycled in the yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put used paper towels in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Nappies and sanitary products
instructions: Wrap used nappies
Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Cannot be recycled or composted
commonMistakes: Don't put nappies in recycling or compost bins

materials.name: Light globes (non-fluorescent)
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: NOT accepted in yellow-lid recycling bin
Fluorescent tubes and CFLs are hazardous — take to a drop-off point
commonMistakes: Don't put light globes in the yellow-lid or purple-lid bin
Don't put fluorescent tubes in general waste — they contain mercury

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Mirror glass is coated and cannot be recycled with container glass
commonMistakes: Don't put mirrors in the purple-lid glass bin

materials.name: Window glass and sheet glass
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
Label as 'broken glass' for safety
notes: Window glass is treated differently from container glass and cannot go in the purple-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put window glass in the purple-lid glass bin

materials.name: Crockery and ceramics
instructions: Wrap broken pieces carefully
Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling — never put in the purple-lid or yellow-lid bin
Donate intact items to op shops instead
commonMistakes: Don't put crockery in the purple-lid glass bin or yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Drinking glasses and pyrex
instructions: Wrap in newspaper or cardboard
Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Different melting point from container glass — contaminates recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put drinking glasses or pyrex in the purple-lid glass bin

materials.name: Waxed cardboard
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: The wax coating prevents the cardboard from being recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put waxed cardboard in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Bioplastics and compostable plastics
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: NOT accepted in Melbourne's yellow-lid recycling bin
NOT accepted in the green-lid FOGO bin either
Bioplastics contaminate both recycling and composting streams
commonMistakes: Don't put bioplastics in recycling or compost bins

materials.name: Plastic straws, cutlery, and stirrers
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Too small and lightweight to be sorted at recycling facilities
Victoria has banned single-use plastics — switch to reusable
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic cutlery in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Not accepted in the green-lid FOGO bin
commonMistakes: Don't put pet waste in the green-lid bin

materials.name: Thermal receipts
instructions: Place in the general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Thermal paper contains BPA — contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put receipts in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do NOT place in any kerbside bin
Take to a battery recycling drop-off point
Tape the terminals of lithium batteries before transport
notes: Batteries can cause fires in rubbish trucks and recycling facilities
Drop-off at Officeworks, Aldi, Battery World, or council events
commonMistakes: NEVER put batteries in the red-lid or yellow-lid bin — fire risk

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Do NOT place in any kerbside bin
Take to a council e-waste drop-off event or collection point
Officeworks accepts small e-waste items
notes: E-waste contains valuable materials that can be recovered
City of Melbourne runs regular e-waste collection events
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in the red-lid bin — they contain hazardous materials

materials.name: Paint and household chemicals
instructions: Do NOT place in any kerbside bin
Take to a Detox Your Home event or transfer station
Keep in original containers with labels
notes: Sustainability Victoria runs Detox Your Home events across Melbourne
Never pour chemicals down the drain
commonMistakes: Never pour paint or chemicals down the drain or into any bin

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes and CFL globes
instructions: Do NOT place in any kerbside bin
Take to a participating retailer (Bunnings) or council event
notes: Contain small amounts of mercury
Handle carefully to avoid breakage
commonMistakes: Don't put fluorescent tubes in the red-lid or yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Sharps and needles
instructions: Place in an approved sharps container
Return full containers to a pharmacy or community health centre
Do NOT place loose in any bin
notes: Free sharps containers available from pharmacies
Never place loose sharps in any kerbside bin
commonMistakes: NEVER put loose needles or sharps in any bin — serious injury risk to workers

materials.name: Motor oil and cooking oil (large amounts)
instructions: Do NOT pour down the drain
Take motor oil to a service station or council transfer station
Small amounts of cooking oil can be absorbed with newspaper and placed in red-lid bin
notes: Motor oil is recycled and re-refined
Never pour oil down the sink or storm drain
commonMistakes: Never pour oil down the drain — it pollutes waterways

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Return to any pharmacy — RUM (Return Unwanted Medicines) program
Pharmacies accept expired or unwanted medications for free
notes: RUM Project is a free national program
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Gas bottles and cylinders
instructions: Take to a gas supplier or council transfer station
Never put in any kerbside bin
notes: Pressurised containers are explosion risks in waste trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate wearable items to op shops (Vinnies, Salvos, Red Cross)
Place in charity clothing bins
Unusable textiles can go in the red-lid bin as a last resort
notes: Do NOT put clothing in the yellow-lid recycling bin
Many charities accept worn or damaged textiles for recycling into rags
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing or textiles in the yellow-lid recycling bin

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Check your council for hard waste collection
Or take to a waste transfer station
notes: Many Melbourne councils offer annual or on-request hard waste collection
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally — fines apply
Remove doors from fridges for safety

materials.name: Container Deposit Scheme (CDS Vic — 10c refund)
instructions: Take eligible containers to a CDS Vic collection point or reverse vending machine
Eligible containers have a 10c refund mark
Find your nearest at cdsvic.org.au
notes: Victoria's Container Deposit Scheme launched in 2023
Most aluminium cans, glass bottles, plastic bottles, and small cartons are eligible
Refund is 10 cents per container
commonMistakes: Not all containers are eligible — look for the 10c refund mark
Don't crush containers — barcode needed for scanning

recycle: Paper and cardboard — newspaper, magazines, junk mail, office paper, egg cartons (flatten boxes)
Cardboard boxes, cereal boxes, pizza boxes (remove food, flatten)
Plastic bottles #1 (PET) — clear water and soft drink bottles only (remove wrapper)
Plastic #2 (HDPE) — milk bottles, detergent bottles, cleaning bottles, shampoo bottles
Plastic #5 (PP) — yoghurt tubs, butter tubs, ice cream containers, food containers, meat trays
Aluminium foil (scrunched to tennis ball size)
Metal cans — aluminium drink cans, steel food cans
Metal lids (placed inside a metal can)
Cartons — milk, juice, soy milk, stock cartons (remove plastic caps)
Glass bottles and jars — in the SEPARATE purple-lid glass bin only
compost: All food scraps (fruit, veg, meat, bones, dairy, bread, rice, pasta)
Tea bags, coffee grounds, and paper coffee filters
Garden waste (grass, leaves, prunings, weeds, flowers)
trash: Aerosol cans — NOT accepted in yellow-lid bin in Melbourne

recycle: Glass — must go in the SEPARATE purple-lid bin, NOT the yellow-lid bin
Aerosol cans — NOT accepted in Melbourne's yellow-lid bin
Loose plastic lids and caps — fall through sorting machinery
Soft plastics and plastic bags — jam sorting machinery
Polystyrene foam cups, trays, and packaging
Disposable coffee cups, tissues, paper towels
compost: Plastic bags (even 'biodegradable' ones unless certified compostable)

tips: Melbourne has THREE kerbside bins: yellow-lid (recycling), purple-lid (glass), green-lid (FOGO)
Glass goes in the SEPARATE purple-lid bin — NOT the yellow-lid recycling bin
Only plastics #1 (PET clear), #2 (HDPE), and #5 (PP) are accepted — very restrictive
Aerosol cans are NOT accepted in the yellow-lid bin in Melbourne
Remove plastic caps from cartons before recycling — loose plastic lids not accepted
Scrunch aluminium foil into a ball at least the size of a tennis ball
Flatten cardboard boxes to save space in the yellow-lid bin
Never bag your recyclables — place items loose in the yellow-lid bin
Metal lids should be placed inside a metal can (pinch top shut) to prevent them falling through sorting
Use the CDS Vic scheme for 10c refund on eligible containers (cdsvic.org.au)
When in doubt, put it in the red-lid bin — contamination ruins recycling

locations.name: CDS Vic Collection Points
locations.notes: 10c refund per eligible container. Multiple collection points and reverse vending machines across Melbourne.

locations.name: Bunnings (various locations)
locations.notes: Free drop-off for CFL/fluorescent tubes and paint. Multiple Melbourne locations.

locations.name: Charity Clothing Bins (Vinnies, Salvos, Red Cross)
locations.notes: Located throughout Melbourne metro area. Only donate clean, dry items in wearable condition.

locations.name: City of Melbourne Transfer Station
locations.notes: Check melbourne.vic.gov.au for nearest transfer station and accepted items.

locations.name: Detox Your Home (Sustainability Victoria)
locations.notes: Free drop-off events run across Melbourne. Check Sustainability Victoria website for dates and locations.
